results.title: Decisive Battles of World War II: Ardennes Offensive for PC
results.creator_credit: Strategic Simulations, Inc. and Strategic Studies Group
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM, CD jewel case with insert, manual, read me guide, registration card and epilepsy warning in cardboard box
results.brief_description: Decisive Battles of WWII: Ardennes Offensive is the first game in the Decisive Battles of WWII series. It is a turn-based strategy wargame set in the Battle of the Bulge. The player can play as either the Germans or Americans, with the British as an AI-controlled third faction. Gameplay is primarily set on a hexagonal grid map with regiments being represented by icons. In each turn, which represents a half day, the player can move units or attack enemy units. A unit’s effectiveness can be augmented by several factors like artillery or airstrikes. The game comes with eight scenarios with a varying number of turns in which to complete them. These scenarios can be played against the computer or against friends in hot seat, LAN, online or play-by-email modes.

results.title: Decisions, Decisions! (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Illustrates problems managers can encounter when failing to approach decision making and implementation logically. Demonstrates the importance of utilising the knowledge and views of the team when deciding on matters affecting them. Famous decision makers from the past, Brutus, Queen Elizabeth I, Churchill and Montgomery, act as a review panel and confront an incompetent manager with his mistakes. Features John Cleese and Prunella Scales. FOR USE ONLY IN A DOMESTIC SITUATION OR FOR EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES ONLY.

results.title: Decisions, decisions (NP)
results.brief_description: Illustrates some of the problems an office manager can come up against if he fails to approach decision making and implementation in a logical manner. Demonstrates how important it is for managers to use the knowledge and views of their team when deciding on matters that affect the team. Famous decision makers from the past, Brutus, Queen Elizabeth I, Churchill, Montgomery act as a review panel and confront an incompetent manager with his mistakes. Features John Cleese. FOR USE ONLY IN A DOMESTIC SITUATION OR FOR EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES ONLY.

results.title: Decisions in academic departments
results.creator_credit: George Pashuk and University of New South Wales. Tertiary Education Research Centre
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Trigger series 7. Managing people”.
Six dramatisations dealing with interpersonal aspects of staff management are designed to trigger discussion. Although set in a university the issues raised are common to all organisations.

results.title: Decisions
results.creator_credit: CRM Educational Films and Stephen Judson
results.brief_description: Covers a variety of situations requiring decision-making ranging from the simple to the complex. Outlines practical procedures and psychological aspects such as anxiety, self-doubt and the fear of being wrong. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Decision for chemistry
results.creator_credit: MPO Productions, Monsanto Chemical Company and Sidney Meyers
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the importance of the chemical industry and its role in everyday living. Mentions the development of fire-resistant materials, treatment of soil with phosphates and Krilium products; the use of detergents in the laundry industry; the development of new textile fibres; and research on radio-active materials. For modern youth, with an enquiring mind, wonderful opportunities for a worth-while career are offered by the chemical industry.

results.brief_description: A promotional film aimed at British residents. Shows an English family who have applied to emigrate to Australia under the Assisted Passage Scheme. Shows the many attractions of Sydney.

results.title: Deciding to organize
results.creator_credit: Bonnie Sherr Klein and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Organizing for Power”.
Produced as a part of the Challenge for Change Program, this series examines Saul Alinsky’s method of organizing communities into effective action units based on participation democracy. A group of concerned citizens from Dayton, Ohio, consult Alinsky on means of creating an effective organization.

results.title: Deciding a future
results.creator_credit: UNICEF, William Hetzer and Edward King
results.brief_description: UNICEF believes that a well organized and involved community that mobilizes itself for a change is performing a needed activity. This program shows how community participation has become an active means of development in Lima, Bangkok and New York.

results.title: Decidedly out of this world
results.creator_credit: Joan Rossi and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: In 1939, Prime Minister Menzies announced that Britain was at war with Germany and that, as a result, Australia is at war with Germany. Joan Rossi talks about how she joined the army in 1941 and subsequent training, her work as a Syphon Officer, moving to Brisbane and tells of how she decoded the sinking of the ship Centaur. Post war, Joan still helped out at RAAF, helping other women find work before finding her own job and settling into post war life
results.description: In 1939, Prime Minister Menzies announced that Britain was at war with Germany and that, as a result, Australia is at war with Germany. Joan Rossi talks about how she joined the army in 1941 and subsequent training, her work as a Syphon Officer, moving to Brisbane and tells of how she decoded the sinking of the ship Centaur. Post war, Joan still helped out at RAAF, helping other women find work before finding her own job and settling into post war life
description_for_label: In 1939, Prime Minister Menzies announced that Britain was at war with Germany and that, as a result, Australia is at war with Germany. Joan Rossi talks about how she joined the army in 1941 and subsequent training, her work as a Syphon Officer, moving to Brisbane and tells of how she decoded the sinking of the ship Centaur. Post war, Joan still helped out at RAAF, helping other women find work before finding her own job and settling into post war life
